Hopkins Stack Throws Soot;
Examined by City Hygiene Dept.
Faced with a barrage of complaints concerning the emission
of cinder and other solid material from the smoke stack behind Whitehead Hall, John W.
Peach, assistant plant manager,
met Tuesday with officials from
the City Health Department's
Bureau of Industrial Hygiene.
After the meeting, Peach told
the News-Letter that the improper functioning of the plant
boiler, resulting in the emission
of large quantities of soot and
flying ash, has been corrected,
and that he and city officials are
currently discussing ways of lessening the amount of refuse material released through the smoke
stack,
The City Health Department,
for the past two weeks, has received as many as twenty-five
complaints a day from residents
in the neighborhood of the Hopkins campus. Mr. Peach explained that the excess smoke and
ash released into the area was
due to the light load of fuel under which the boiler had been

Jean-Pierre R am pal and
Robert Veyron-Lacroix, renowned flute and keyboard duo, will
appear at Shrivel' Hall Sunday,
November 7 at 8:30 p.m. Tickets
are on sale at the Public Relations office at $1.00 for students
and $2.25 general admission.
The duo of Rampal/VeyronLacroix has tdured throughout

indicated in words, and Mr.

SAIS Initiates Fall Term;
Curriculum Will Stress
Military Power Policy
The Johns Hopkins School of
Advanced International Studies
in Washington, D.C. will begin
its fifteenth academic year this
week when 180 graduate students
enroll in programs leading to the
Master of Arts degree in International Relations. Forty-five
courses will be offered, including
a course on military power in

appointed Director of the Washington Center of Foreign Policy

Sc INVESTIGATES ITSELF
FOR FIRST LEGISLATION
One of the Student Council's
major projects this semester
Will be a thorough investigation
Of its own composition. A committee, headed by Barry Gould,
Honor Commission representative, was formed last June to
consider both the size of the
Council and the composition of
its representatives.
Two years ago the Student
Council underwent an extensive
reorganization in which representatives from the YMCA, the
-13SRC and other major campus
organizations were given a vote.
The question confronting the
Committee is whether it would
be better to eliminate these special members and enlarge the
Council by adding more members from each class, giving the
students wider representation.
The final report of the committee should be ready in two weeks.
In other action at its meeting
on Monday night, President
Shelly Earp announced the first
annual Student Council lecture
to be given by William Buckley,
currently candidate for mayor
Of New York, on December 14th.
Also sponsored by the Council
Will be an architectural tour of
Baltimore led by Dr. Phoebe
Stanton of the Hopkins Art DeDartment on Saturday, October
30th.
Jeff Griffith, chairman of the
social committee and president
Of the Booster Club announced a
dance on Saturday, October 23rd,
to be held in the gym as a conclusion to the Big Fall Weekend.
Jeff will also be in charge of the
Freshman Spirit Committee. It
and the Intown Students Committee will provide the class of

One other committee report
remains to be presented, that of
the Gentleman's Code committee. In the Past questions of nonacademic violations of the Hopkins Gentleman's Code have
been handled by the Dean. Last
year the Council was requested
several times to investigate some
of these alleged violations, which
led to the suggestion that some
responsible student authority be
established to handle all such
cases, subject to the final approval of the Dean. Over the
summer the committee has been
corresponding with other schools
and studying their systems of
handling these violations and
giving a great deal of thought
to establishing some sort of
workable system here at Hopkins,
if indeed one is possible.

Votes For Decency
The administrative stand on carrying alcoholic
beverages or containers into the stadium has brought
to the fore questions regarding the University's right
In such authority, anti whether such authority should
extend to matters of morality.
The ban does not represent a moral judgment, but
one of expediency. It is not an imposition on student
freedom (a pattern of action that strikes dread into
the hearts of those who value their liberties beyond their
worth) nor an action for the protection of the purity of
the young men's minds, but a device for the protection
of the University,
In substances, the ruling aims at regulating the
alcohol flow into the stands; in method, it aims to
regulate the kind of people that enter. But in kind, the
ruling has no other goal than to keep the appearance
of the University away from evil.
In fact, it is a clever ruling. One can rightly infer
that if a person is able to conceal enough spirits on his
person to pass inspection at the gate, then he deserves to
have his booze and drink it too.
And 88 a point of information, Hopkins is not alone
in such an attempt to curb the consequences of drinking.
Princeton has Initiated a similar program of discipline.
The public image of the University, for better or
worse, very much controls its purse strings. If the University, out of sympathy for the unobstructed freedom
of the student, or out of mere negligence, allowed this
image to he defaced, the University would be working
against itself.
In literature, the anti-novel, the anti-poem anti the
anti-play have been given status partly because they are
peculiar in their unusual trait of defeating or reversing
their own purpose. Their status is based much on curiosity. The invulnerability of traditions in literature, and
in truth, the independence of the creative arts from
world opinion allows for such exploration.
An Anti-University, on the other hand, is entirely
impractical. And the administration's attempt to restore
some order to sports speetatordom is an implementation of that thesis.
The following editorial was written by Larry Schmidt, President of the Inter-fraternity Council.

The recent administrative action regarding the
transportation of packaged goods and the admittance
of undesirable elements to the Homewood stadium has
led, naturally enough, to much discussion among fraternity members.
It has been the practice in the past years for fraternities to sit together in the stands, and it has further
been the practice, in general, for members to bring
refreshments of alcoholic content to the games. Conseplenty, the administrative action directly affects the
fraternity system as a whole since this practice was a
common one among some fraternities. At this point it
must be emphasized that although the fraternities have
been responsible for bringing some packaged liquor to
the game, they are by no means directly responsible for
the action taken. President Eisenhower, and Deans
Schaeffer, Morrill, and Strider have made it quite clear
that the outside visitors have played a considerable role
in the formulation of this policy, and, by this, reference
is made to area high school students and visiting alumni.
Granted, in some instances the privilege, and it was a
privilege and not a right, was abused by Hopkins students, both independents and fraternity men. But this
privilege had also become free license for the community at large to come to the Hopkins' campus on Saturday afternoon to "tie on" a cheap and unprohibited
drunk. The result has been a blight on the Hopkins'
name and both verbal and financial reprisals by those
of the non-Hopkins community who have special interests in the institution.
The administration had willingly approached this
problem over the past few years with the students' interests in mind. To date no system, student vigilante or

Once-Beaten Gridders Take On
Ursinus in Home Opener Sat.
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Chugging away from a strong
losing performance in its season
opener, the varsity football team
Invites further trouble tomorrow,
hosting Ursinus to start the '65
home grid schedule. Kickoff time
is 2:00 p.m.
Ursinus, a 22-7 loser to Muhlenburg last week, boasts an excellent ground game headed by
5 9", 205 pound fullback Dave
Raub, a strong inside runner who
led the Southern Division M.A.C.
In rushing last year, and 5'8",
195 pound junior halfback Tony
Motto, the Eastern Collegiate
Athletic Conference's outstanding sophomore of 1964.
Leading the way for this formidable twosome is a big veteran
line with good depth, much like
the one that finally proved to be
the Jays' undoing last week.
Secondary Weak
Muhlenburg made ample use
of the airways in scoring their
three touchdowns a week ago,
exploiting weaknesses iLl Ursinus'
secondary.
In last week's 27-14 loss to
Franklin and Marshall, the Jays
had parlayed two Phil Parthmore-to-Walt Siggers touchdown passes into a 14-7 third
period lead before the Diplomats,
Southern Division M.A.C. favorites, staged a late rally to push
their winning streak to nine
games.
Line Thin
"What beat us was lack of
depth in the line," opined Coach
Wilson Fewster, "since our boys
were pretty well worn down by
the middle of the third period.
F&M had a fine veteran group
up front with plenty of reserves,
and they used about all of them.

"All in all, though, it was
probably one of our better opening games", continued the varsity mentor, "considering the
fact that we started seven sophomores and were generally inexperienced."
Transplanted Backs
''The ground game was not all
I could have wished, but, considering the fact that we started
two players without much experience at their particular positions, and two who hadn't played
competitive football in over a
year, things weren't too bad."
A look at unofficial rushing
statistics bears out Fewster's
point. The Jays gained 86 yards
in 17 carries, an average of over
five yards a try, but too much of
it cames in big chunks, as the
team was unable to mount a
sustained ground attack.
Parthmore Stars
The squad's prime offensive
movement came on the strength
of the passing of junior Parthmore, who completed ten of

nineteen tosses for 105 yards and
the two touchdowns. Five of his
passes went to All-Maryland end
Mike Oidick.
Parthmore's performance looks
even better when compared to
that of FezM's Seiki Murono,
who though running well, had a
tough time in the air, partially
because of poor receiving. The
third - string All-Pennsylvania
pick completed seven of sixteen
for eighty-four yards.
Standouts Tabbed
Tabbed as offensive standouts
by Fewster were Parthmore, Siggers, and Oidick, while defensively high praise came for Denny Ferrazzano's work at middle
linebacker and the tackling of
Jim Calli and Bob Shannon in
the secondary.
Returning to action this week
will be third string quarterback
and defensive starter Mike Shaw,
who will excuse Parthmore from
playing both ways. Lineman Mike
Gersick is also expected to see
slight action.

broken when the Gettysburg
goalie collided with a fullback,

Warren Isom, on a pass from
John Taylor, scored Hopkins'
last goal in the fourth quarter.

one of the better teams we face,
we did smooth out some problems," stated Barrette. "Our

Hopkins Stack Throws Soot;
Examined by City Hygiene Dept.
Faced with a barrage of complaints concerning the emission
of cinder and other solid material from the smoke stack behind Whitehead Hall, John W.
Peach, assistant plant manager,
met Tuesday with officials from
the City Health Department's
Bureau of Industrial Hygiene.
After the meeting, Peach told
the News-Letter that the improper functioning of the plant
boiler, resulting in the emission
of large quantities of soot and
flying ash, has been corrected,
and that he and city officials are
currently discussing ways of lessening the amount of refuse material released through the smoke
stack,
The City Health Department,
for the past two weeks, has received as many as twenty-five
complaints a day from residents
in the neighborhood of the Hopkins campus. Mr. Peach explained that the excess smoke and
ash released into the area was
due to the light load of fuel under which the boiler had been

Sc INVESTIGATES ITSELF
FOR FIRST LEGISLATION
One of the Student Council's
major projects this semester
Will be a thorough investigation
Of its own composition. A committee, headed by Barry Gould,
Honor Commission representative, was formed last June to
consider both the size of the
Council and the composition of
its representatives.
Two years ago the Student
Council underwent an extensive
reorganization in which representatives from the YMCA, the
-13SRC and other major campus
organizations were given a vote.
The question confronting the
Committee is whether it would
be better to eliminate these special members and enlarge the
Council by adding more members from each class, giving the
students wider representation.
The final report of the committee should be ready in two weeks.
In other action at its meeting
on Monday night, President
Shelly Earp announced the first
annual Student Council lecture
to be given by William Buckley,
currently candidate for mayor
Of New York, on December 14th.
Also sponsored by the Council
Will be an architectural tour of
Baltimore led by Dr. Phoebe
Stanton of the Hopkins Art DeDartment on Saturday, October
30th.
Jeff Griffith, chairman of the
social committee and president
Of the Booster Club announced a
dance on Saturday, October 23rd,
to be held in the gym as a conclusion to the Big Fall Weekend.
Jeff will also be in charge of the
Freshman Spirit Committee. It
and the Intown Students Committee will provide the class of

Votes For Decency
The administrative stand on carrying alcoholic
beverages or containers into the stadium has brought
to the fore questions regarding the University's right
In such authority, anti whether such authority should
extend to matters of morality.
The ban does not represent a moral judgment, but
one of expediency. It is not an imposition on student
freedom (a pattern of action that strikes dread into
the hearts of those who value their liberties beyond their
worth) nor an action for the protection of the purity of
the young men's minds, but a device for the protection
of the University,
In substances, the ruling aims at regulating the
alcohol flow into the stands; in method, it aims to
regulate the kind of people that enter. But in kind, the
ruling has no other goal than to keep the appearance
of the University away from evil.
In fact, it is a clever ruling. One can rightly infer
that if a person is able to conceal enough spirits on his
person to pass inspection at the gate, then he deserves to
have his booze and drink it too.
And 88 a point of information, Hopkins is not alone
in such an attempt to curb the consequences of drinking.
Princeton has Initiated a similar program of discipline.
The public image of the University, for better or
worse, very much controls its purse strings. If the University, out of sympathy for the unobstructed freedom
of the student, or out of mere negligence, allowed this
image to he defaced, the University would be working
against itself.
In literature, the anti-novel, the anti-poem anti the
anti-play have been given status partly because they are
peculiar in their unusual trait of defeating or reversing
their own purpose. Their status is based much on curiosity. The invulnerability of traditions in literature, and
in truth, the independence of the creative arts from
world opinion allows for such exploration.
An Anti-University, on the other hand, is entirely
impractical. And the administration's attempt to restore
some order to sports speetatordom is an implementation of that thesis.
The following editorial was written by Larry Schmidt, President of the Inter-fraternity Council.

The recent administrative action regarding the
transportation of packaged goods and the admittance
of undesirable elements to the Homewood stadium has
led, naturally enough, to much discussion among fraternity members.
It has been the practice in the past years for fraternities to sit together in the stands, and it has further
been the practice, in general, for members to bring
refreshments of alcoholic content to the games. Conseplenty, the administrative action directly affects the
fraternity system as a whole since this practice was a
common one among some fraternities. At this point it
must be emphasized that although the fraternities have
been responsible for bringing some packaged liquor to
the game, they are by no means directly responsible for
the action taken. President Eisenhower, and Deans
Schaeffer, Morrill, and Strider have made it quite clear
that the outside visitors have played a considerable role
in the formulation of this policy, and, by this, reference
is made to area high school students and visiting alumni.
Granted, in some instances the privilege, and it was a
privilege and not a right, was abused by Hopkins students, both independents and fraternity men. But this
privilege had also become free license for the community at large to come to the Hopkins' campus on Saturday afternoon to "tie on" a cheap and unprohibited
drunk. The result has been a blight on the Hopkins'
name and both verbal and financial reprisals by those
of the non-Hopkins community who have special interests in the institution.
The administration had willingly approached this
problem over the past few years with the students' interests in mind. To date no system, student vigilante or
otherwise, had met with anything but a modicum of success at best, and it was generally agreed among the situ(Continued on Page 6)

Pi, Phi Gamma Delta, Phi Sigma

fraternity system in the life of
the undergraduate."

Y Meeting
The YMCA will hold a meeting
for all its members on Tuesday,

be explained to the members.
This is an especially good time
for freshmen to begin participating in the various activities

include: tutoring, enrichment

PAGE TEN

Once-Beaten Gridders Take On
Ursinus in Home Opener Sat.
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Chugging away from a strong
losing performance in its season
opener, the varsity football team
Invites further trouble tomorrow,
hosting Ursinus to start the '65
home grid schedule. Kickoff time
is 2:00 p.m.
Ursinus, a 22-7 loser to Muhlenburg last week, boasts an excellent ground game headed by
5 9", 205 pound fullback Dave
Raub, a strong inside runner who
led the Southern Division M.A.C.
In rushing last year, and 5'8",
195 pound junior halfback Tony
Motto, the Eastern Collegiate
Athletic Conference's outstanding sophomore of 1964.
Leading the way for this formidable twosome is a big veteran
line with good depth, much like
the one that finally proved to be
the Jays' undoing last week.
Secondary Weak
Muhlenburg made ample use
of the airways in scoring their
three touchdowns a week ago,
exploiting weaknesses iLl Ursinus'
secondary.
In last week's 27-14 loss to
Franklin and Marshall, the Jays
had parlayed two Phil Parthmore-to-Walt Siggers touchdown passes into a 14-7 third
period lead before the Diplomats,
Southern Division M.A.C. favorites, staged a late rally to push
their winning streak to nine
games.
Line Thin
"What beat us was lack of
depth in the line," opined Coach
Wilson Fewster, "since our boys
were pretty well worn down by
the middle of the third period.
F&M had a fine veteran group
up front with plenty of reserves,
and they used about all of them.

"All in all, though, it was
probably one of our better opening games", continued the varsity mentor, "considering the
fact that we started seven sophomores and were generally inexperienced."
Transplanted Backs
''The ground game was not all
I could have wished, but, considering the fact that we started
two players without much experience at their particular positions, and two who hadn't played
competitive football in over a
year, things weren't too bad."
A look at unofficial rushing
statistics bears out Fewster's
point. The Jays gained 86 yards
in 17 carries, an average of over
five yards a try, but too much of
it cames in big chunks, as the
team was unable to mount a
sustained ground attack.
Parthmore Stars
The squad's prime offensive
movement came on the strength
of the passing of junior Parthmore, who completed ten of

nineteen tosses for 105 yards and
the two touchdowns. Five of his
passes went to All-Maryland end
Mike Oidick.
Parthmore's performance looks
even better when compared to
that of FezM's Seiki Murono,
who though running well, had a
tough time in the air, partially
because of poor receiving. The
third - string All-Pennsylvania
pick completed seven of sixteen
for eighty-four yards.
Standouts Tabbed
Tabbed as offensive standouts
by Fewster were Parthmore, Siggers, and Oidick, while defensively high praise came for Denny Ferrazzano's work at middle
linebacker and the tackling of
Jim Calli and Bob Shannon in
the secondary.
Returning to action this week
will be third string quarterback
and defensive starter Mike Shaw,
who will excuse Parthmore from
playing both ways. Lineman Mike
Gersick is also expected to see
slight action.

Pitchmen Tromp Gettysburg;
Host Strong Delaware Tues.
By MARSHALL PAUL
Coach Gary Barrette's entire
front line scored Wednesday as
the varsity soccer team ran down
Gettysburg 5-0.
The pitchmen, who host Delaware Tuesday, were given a twopoint edge at the end of the
first half on goals by Gondis
Gucer and Wes Bachur. Pablo
Drobny got the assist on Gucer's
goal. Bachur's tally, from the
right corner, was unassisted.
Gettysburg came out strong in
the next half, but its spirit was
broken when the Gettysburg
goalie collided with a fullback,
allowing Drobny to niche another point. Two minutes later,
Drobny assisted again, this time
with soph Kit Battenfeld scoring.
Warren Isom, on a pass from
John Taylor, scored Hopkins'
last goal in the fourth quarter.
"Although Gettysburg is not
one of the better teams we face,
we did smooth out some problems," stated Barrette. "Our
fullbacks played better, and our

On Rifle Team's '65 Slate
The varsity rifle team will be
competing this year with nationally-ranked West Virginia, Navy,
Penn Military College, and Penn
State, Captain Larry Caruthers
announced.
In addition to competing in
dual or triangular matches with
these teams, the Blue Jays will
compete in the annual U.S. Coast
guard
Academy
Invitational
tournament in March.

year, captured the third-high

defense was solid. tMarv) Ortel
did a fine job in the goal."
The coach also cited the play
of Lucky Mallonee, Jim Zeverly,
and Bob Knauff, who bottled up
Gettysburg's All-America pick
Ron Nix.
The Jays preceded this game
with a 2-0 opening loss to Dickinson. The host club used all of
Its seventeen returning lettermen
to take a 1-0 half time lead.
"We came out like terrors in
the third quarter," recalled Barrette. "We pressed them into
making a foul but their goalie
made a fantastic save to stop our
penalty kick"
The Jays continued to press
for another five minutes, letting
Dickinson out of its defensive
area only twice in that quarter.
However, Dickinson ecked out a
second point when a fullback
shielded the Hopkins goalie, allowing a shot to dribble in.
Delaware, whom the.Jays meet
next, should be strong, according
to Barrette.
